reviewText: Has a fair few rough edges but it doesn't hold back on being a fantastic WWE game. Very pleased for it to be released on PC - what we have all been waiting for! Graphics are much improved over previous titles, and the gameplay is as good as its ever been. I've seen and heard many people commenting about the slow speed of the wrestling, personally I don't see the problem at all. Its a lot more realistic, and with the stamina mode (unless you disable it) it makes sure you can't run around like a meat-head on steroids without sacrificing lots of energy.\n\nI've played over 80 hours of this now and I still have a small bit left to do, so I've got my moneys worth for sure. Again, other criticisms I've seen was focused on the lack of depth for the game - which I don't understand. Story Mode, WWE Universe Mode, 2K Showcase & Multiplayer have kept me thoroughly entertained throughout. I had to stop and start my Story Mode numerous times though as it did get extremely repetitive, notably through the lack of cut scene storylines/challenges. It is very basic" only offering a handful of times where it really did show some great potential. It does become repetitive
date: but if this is your first time with the game then it won't be as big a problem for you - I owned this on PS4 before getting it on PC so I've already completed everything the game has to offer
recommended: this is just a re-run for me. Expect the Story to last roughly 12-20 hours.\n\nNice to see the community creations progressively getting better and better
hoursPlayed: the ease of applying created costumes to stock characters is a great bonus - therefore you can always keep your roster wardrobe up to date

reviewText:
UPDATE 29/04/2015:
Modding has been confirmed on twitter! Also here is a link to the official 2k15 pc forums specifically for mods: http://forums.2k.com/forumdisplay.php?606-WWE-2K15-(PC)-Mods-Discussion

My review:

I've played WWE 2K15 first on the Xbox 360 and then on the Playstation 4. The reason I bought this for the PC is because I'm looking forward to mods.

Graphics: 9/10
Honestly, the graphics on next gen consoles were a huge improvement over WWE 2K14 and the PC just gives us that full HD 60fps movement. So far I've only experienced one glitch in the replay of the highlights. But I'm sure this will be fixed in time. The character models are far more realistic than the older WWE versions. I only feel like the ramp and outside of the ring could somehow be improved graphically as well as the general arena. I've created my own superstar and played about 7 matches in NXT. I haven't experienced any glitches yet during My Career.

Gameplay: 10/10
Can't say anything negative about the gameplay. I initially expected I would be using a gamepad to play the game but I actually think I might stick with the old keyboard. The mouse isn't actually used. WASD to move around, F to reverse, Q to pick ♥♥♥♥ up and the arrow keys are used to fight. Left key strikes, up key uses your signature/finishing move, down key is grappling and the right key is the old irish whip.

Loading times: 11/10
The loading times are very fast for me. When I turn entrances off and hit enter to go to a match I'm supplexing John Cena within 10 seconds. I'll list my specs at the bottom.

Music: 8/10
The only reason I'm giving this an 8 instead of a 10 is because I've heard these songs hundreds of times and probably memorised them by now. It's a good soundtrack but there's not a lot of songs and they will tire eventually. You obviously have the option to turn the music (or just certain songs) off.

Negative points:
- No Paige
They won't be releasing Paige for the PC any time soon. She was a season pass exclusive for consoles, but since there's no season pass for PC she isn't being released (yet?).

- Not as much customization as previous WWE games
Basically you can't create diva's, which sucks as there aren't many in the game inititally. You also can't create arena's, titles or finishers like previous games. The entrance creation is limited with existing superstars entrances and only a few custom options.

- Not all the DLC is available yet.

If you enjoy WWE and like the look of the gameplay on YouTube etc I recommend you get this. If you only want this for mods then you should probably wait untill people have figured out how to mod the game and there actually are mods out.

My specs:
CPU: Intel Core i7-4770K CPU @ 3.50GHZ (not overclocked)
GPU: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 770
Ram: 16GB
Windows 8.1
Resolution: 1920 x 1080, 60HZ

reviewText:
Summary: *It's rather pointless to force people to pick between 'recommend' and 'not recommend'. In the end, despite issues, one could still recommend this title -- with the hope that many of its issues are addressed eventually -- but there are some real concerns that need highlighting.* This review is subject to revisions, and even a shift in recommendation.

It is understandable --  and to be expected -- that wrestling fans are going to react to this title with a certain bias. Multiple console generations have passed since the PC has had a mainstream wrestling title from the WWE, so the enthusiasm and naive view that it must be 'great' can be excused to a degree. The problem is that many, but not all, of the positive reviews are blatantly overlooking the technical issues and flaws within this game, so this won't be an overall review as it will be an actual overview of the shortcomings that are inherent in this title. These flaws range from actual in-game bugs, to overall game stability, the general uncertainty about the so-called 'included DLCs' (although these can be expected to appear sooner than later given other published claims) the criticisms about lesser options than previous titles, and frame rate issues that do not correlate with the actual recommended system requirements for this title.

Going through the problems in more detail, and these have been verified by other accounts of the game:

- First off, the game has its bugs. From visual glitches and random artefacts like ropes disappearing and reappearing half-way in the middle of the ring, to bodies cliping into the ring as well as the ringside. And no, deactivating FXAA doesn't help. One could actually go on to experience and list more but that would simply be repeating a fundamental issue that a title being released this late as a port should be looking to avoid. If there is one thing the positive reviews do speak to, it is fan/gamer expectation and 2K games is not off to the most graceful of starts, but such is the case in an era where many hopeful titles are coming out as glitchy works in progress on release date.

- Secondly, there is a serious issue with random crashes. It really cannot be excused and arguments from the positive-reviewers about this being an 'isolated issue' is disingenuous at best. One could say that their experience with stability is an isolated experience, but that would be sinking the argument to the levels of their bias. Fact remains that for a sizeable number of people who have paid for this title, the experience with basic game stability is coming up short and this needs to be addressed. Positive reviewers in denial of this can remain in denial but that doesn't mean that their out of touch with reality views actually negate the problem for the consumer base. Again, 2K needs to get on top of this issue.

- The general uncertainty about all the included DLC is more of a minor issue. Since it isn't absolutely clear when this DLC is meant to appear -- we are already approaching the end of spring -- confusion can arise, but one can certainly hope that the consumers can unite on this matter and expect that 2K delivers this content soon, or at least that it offers a more definitive idea of when this content can be expected.

- This takes us to the general issue with the overall quality of this game as a product of the WWE video game franchise. Just because the PC has finally received some modicum of acknowledgement after being ignored for over a decade as a viable gaming platform by games publishers and developers working on WWE titles, doesn't mean that PC gamers should actually drop their standards. It's rather unsettling to watch all the positive reviews float in without a sense of self-awareness when even the next generation console rendition of this title has received plenty of valid criticism. PC gamers should have respectable representation with respectable standards. Fact remains that across the board, the 2K15 title -- despite a hefty graphics engine upgrade -- has undergone an even heftier customisation and broad playability downgrade. It is beyond dispute, and a matter of consensus (has been since this game was released last year on all consoles), that WWE 2K15 is a parred back experience in terms of feature, content and customisation options when compared to earlier entries. Many fans on the current generation have expressed dissatisfaction with this approach. PC gamers, while late to this experience, should not let their desperation and lack of acknowledgement get in the way of valid criticism: they should expect the same as their console counterparts and expect better from 2K games. This title, in terms of feature quality -- for this generation -- is actually verging on being mediocre, and this fact needs to be acknowledged rather than glossed over with the noisy desperation of wrestling devotees in denial. This is actually a rather anaemic, stripped-down title that happens to look great.

- Last, but not least -- probably one of the more important points -- we deal with the recommended system specifications and frame rate issues. Let's not mince words here, this game does erratically switch back and forth on the frame rate spectrum and this can be verified with simple software along with basic observation. It states, clear as day, that the recommended specificatin is an Nvidia GTX 570 or an upper-end Radeon 6 series card. On that note, one can utterly disregard the elitist ramblings of the reviewer with the GTX 780, telling others that the game is 'fine' and they should upgrade their specification. This kind of commentary is utter nonsense at best, and likely spam at worst. It is absolutely beside the point if one has a much better card than recommended specification, and is able to get better frame rates out of a title as a result -- a performance that should be attainable on an older card. In this case, the game is advertising itself with a recommendation of the GTX 570 or equivalent, which should be able to provide quality performance across the board, and this just isn't the case. In fact, it is reasonable to speculate that the performance is inconsistent even with faster cards, as there seems to be some kind of system in the game where the frame rate switches between 30 FPS, 45 FPS and 60 FPS depending on what is taking place on the screen. For example: It generally tends to slow down when the camera zooms in on 'finishers' taking place, but perhaps this was an intended feature and part of the game's cinematography and art direction. The same can be said about certain entrances and other moments within the game. This matter needs to be addressed and they do need to work on making the frame rate output consistent as this title is a direct port of the version published on the current generation of consoles, which has also had trouble keeping up with 60 FPS.

At the end of the day, the fact that this game is now available on PC should probably be considered a good thing and a positive sign of the times. PC gamers have been excluded from wrestling titles for too long. Unfortunately, that doesn't mean that they should lower their standards and overlook the seriously obvious shortcomings of this title. PC gamers, regardless of their enjoyment of the wrestling entertainment industry, really need to get real on this issue and curb their enthusiasm for a moment to favour the task of holding developers up to basic standard. As has been discussed in detail, this game has its flaws from actual bugs, stability issues, to a somewhat uninspiring game design, none of this being helped by inconsistent performance that doesn't correlate with recommended system specification, although that could change. Wrestling fandom desperation or not, the dissatisfaction with these issues absolutely needs to be appreciated and the issues themselves, addressed to reasonable satisfaction.

reviewText:
Not the perfect WWE game by any means, but still really enjoyable nonetheless.

Pro's:
- It's a WWE game on PC!
- I found Universe mode to be really enjoyable
- Wrestlers look great
- Great animations
- Nostalgia factor with a good selection of retired wrestlers
- Great community uploads (Attires, wrestlers not included in the game eg Jeff Hardy, AJ Styles)
- Decent customization, lots of moves

Cons:
- Commentary gets old pretty quick. I miss Good Ol' JR!
- Lack of recent updates to roster, example Reigns, Rollins and Ambrose still have Shield attires and entrance
- Missing match types (No handicap matches, only 1v1 in alot of match types, eg TLC)
- Keyboard contols take a bit of getting used to, in all honesty better with a gamepad

reviewText:
This game is great for wrestling fans who do not have consoles and are tired of playing old WWE games on ps2 or wii emulator but not for a casual gamer who is looking for fighting game. If you liked WWE 2k14 and other older releases of WWE games you will not like this game because it's more realistic simulation of WWE rather than casual fighting game.

My Career mode is very lacking content. Most of times youre fighting random matches without any kind of rivalry. There are only a couple of rivalries in the whole career mode. When you win WWE championship that's it, game over. Because of that I tried not winning championship and get as many rivalries as possible, sadly at the end you are gonna only get championship rivalries no matter which PPV you choose (Every year you can choose in which 3 PPV's you want to participate). Not only that, my career is extremely easy, I easily fought my way to WWE championship without losing a single match. There is no difficulty option. If you are buying this only for my career mode, dont buy.

Universe mode is fun, you can make your own WWE universe with your own rivalries, tag teams, champions and etc. There are a lot of rivalries too you can play.

2K showcase is basically storylines that happened in WWE. If you enjoy completing objectives this is for you.

Creativity is very limited, you can't create a diva. A lot of past WWE installment features are stripped out of this game.

Graphics are beautifull but the optimization is not great

reviewText:
I've never waited so long to be so disappointed.  I bought the game naively hoping to enjoy it after reviews universally panned both console versions.  This is a bad game with very few redeeming qualities.  2K themselves have acknowledged the shortcomings of WWE 2K15, and assert that they want to make next year's installment the best game they possibly can.

It is for that reason that I am glad I bought this.  I want 2K to continue releasing WWE games on this platform.  There *is* a market for WWE games here, so I'll happily bite this particular bullet if it helps to send that message.

Edit:  As of June 2nd, 2015, 2k has released a ~10gb update which integrates DLC and fixes.  This is unquestionably a major improvement in the game, both performance and enjoyability-wise.

reviewText:
After being a huge fan of the wrestling titles on PS1 and PS2 I have to remark on how excited I was to see a PC release after these games being console exclusive games for a long time. The short of it is that everything I loved is gone leaving an incredibly empty game.

I first head to the customisation to find you can't create a Diva, only edit the clothing of a current one, and the body morphing options from both sides of the extreme are kept to realistic standards... why? I don't see what was wrong with making some extreme lard belly or a rake- it was part of the fun. The hairstyles are more or less a template of current WWE superstars and there is barely more than 10 of them so you'll be loving your Cena clones. Masks? There's around 5 and they all look crap. You can't wear some items into the ring such as hats etc which blows my mind. I've never seen such limited character creation in a WWE game.

The gameplay is so bloody stagnant and 'fake'. It's got such a focus on looking good that the developers seem to have forgotten that the fun in wrestling was watching all these crazy moves and finishers, people flying out of the ring and all their little gimmicks. But I really felt I was stuck doing the same two or three moves in a really clunky fight-system. The reversal is a joke where the 'RT' warning pops up and I hit it...too fast"? If I see this guy's ♥♥♥♥ing boot heading to my face you'd think I'd rather be out of the way sooner than later. The grappling system seemed interesting until it came to 'rock
recommended: scissors' with the result often being that myself and the AI picked the same one so the ♥♥♥♥ just cancelled out

reviewText:
Two of my last matches sum this game up:

--------------------------
As Savage vs Hogan, I was being pinned after taking a finisher or two at the end of a match. My manager (Sensational Sherri) smartly distracted the ref as Hogan made the cover, so I had a whole 10 seconds to get my escape marker in my 'pin escape' zone. And I discovered... I couldn't. You hold a button to fill the bar, but it goes up in increments. The two possible escape marker placements I could hit were on either side of the pin escape zone. I had been covered by the impossible pin; I lost.

Taker vs Lesnar - Recreating the WM match, it was awesome and 'realistic'. I kicked out of the last ride, he kicked out of the F5, I reversed the Tombstone. An epic, brutal, long match back and forth. I took it to the outside, Taker threw me into the turnbuckle post and got back in. I got up to my feet at 9 (how dramatic!) and ran to the ring... and Brock wouldn't get in, just spazzing out next to the ring. Ref counted 10, the Taker/Lesnar WM XXX match ends in count out. Because the game won't let you get back in unless you're inbetween two invisible barriers. The instant rematch was just a generic WWE 2K15 match; the moment was gone. Thanks game.
-------------

This sums it up because, as you can see, the potential is now there for an amazing simulation and experience, but it doesn't achieve it due to stupidity and laziness mostly.

Everyone rejoiced when the series was finally removed from the cold, dead, lazy fingers of THQ and Yukes. The intention is clearly there from 2K to bring it back to its peak of around 2006. But on the other hand, so much has been removed through the years that this edition is basically half a 'Smackdown vs Raw 2007'. Plus, I worry about the integrity of a company that finishes some content before release THEN removes it and charges extra for it (on consoles) as DLC. Leaving you with half a game mode as default unless you shell out more (though PC gets it free).

Let's not even get into the slowdown, intentional(!) blurriness and bugs.

The game's still good for enjoying the historic game mode (called '2K Showcase' now), just as with Attitude Era and the WrestleMania history in WWE 13 and 2K14. However, nothing else is worth playing. Career mode is a load of singles 'dark' matches, and when you finally win the title after 4 game years, a screen comes up saying '...after winning the WWE title, you went on to have an illustrious career for 15 years, then retired. GAME OVER.'

To top it off, it's said by your boss Triple H. The guy who's been ruining careers for a couple of decades now. Awesomely fitting.

That literally happens. It's not from The Simpsons, it's not satire, THIS ACTUALLY HAPPENS.

Now you see why you should be worried about the people making this game. They either thought this made sense, or they couldn't be bothered to finish it. THQ have been ousted by a coup, but it turns out our new 2K rulers are just as crooked as the despot they just executed.

Universe mode continues to be repetitive and meaningless. There needs to be interactivity, it needs to be less of a cluster-♥♥♥♥, and it needs to be more accessible and friendlier. It needs storylines, not a bunch of matches with the odd non-interactive cutscene of Bloke A beating up Bloke B for 4 weeks, with Mark Henry wrestling 3 times a show because he has 3 costumes or versions of himself.

It appears the problem with WWE games is the same problem with WWE itself: when you have no competition, why bother? You can half-♥♥♥ it and make about as much money than if you had put the work in and made an 8, 9, 10/10 game.

reviewText:
Ok here is my bullet point review for WWE 2k15

Gameplay

This game plays similar to the last few WWE games on consoles. One button attacks, one grapples. R trigger (on game pads) will block, holding a direction with a grapple or punch will change the move that you do. Nothing outside of the wrestling game controls standards here.

The difference to the gameplay in this game as compared to WWE 13 or 14 is really all in the move animations. While you may pull all of the moves off the same way that you have for the last few years, they are all animated differently. So much so that it does in fact make this appear to be a completely different game at first glance.

The new animations are both a blessing and a curse. While 2K have done a pretty amazing job and making the action on your monitor look very close to the action on your television every Monday night, they have done so by bringing back a few gameplay elements that their predecessor had already tried out and removed from the game for good reason.

First prematch mini games. These were brought in by THQ is the early days of the Smackdown vs. RAW series. Back then the mini game was only your opening move and while some liked the idea, the majority cried foul. It didn't take THQ long to remove the mini games from the WWE games. So why did 2K not only decide that it was a good idea to bring this concept back, but to make you have to play these mini games for your first 5 to 10 moves?

Granted this time the mini games open the match with a series of chain wrestling moves that mimic what you would see on TV, but the problem is most people don't want to play them. Imagine, you and a friend select your fighters. You pick your match type, you're ready to lay the smackdown on your chums candy ♥♥♥ and then, oh wait mini game chain wrestling!

The next item that 2K brought back to the series is hitting a button to perform a move and then watching a 5 to 10 second series of animations. sometimes it can feel so bad that you may think that you are playing a QTE game. One example is a character that has a series of kicks as his signature move (YES!) Prepare to sit back and watch each and every one of those kicks play out with just a single button press. The other problem lies in the repositioning of the wrestlers. Seriously, when I decide to lock in the Scorpion Deathlock near the ropes, I shouldn't have to watch Sting grab the opponent and move him to the center of the ring, casually walk around him, and then finally apply the move. I can only assume that this feature was put in to try and avoid clipping with the new animations.

The problem however is this. First if I apply a submission near the ropes I am going to get a rope break called (in a standard match). This is an error on my part and I should pay for it, just like the wrestlers do every week on RAW. The other problem is that this stuff really snaps you out of the game. I hate to beat a dead horse, but look to No Mercy or Here Comes the Pain. Both games did a good job of sucking you into their world. There was no time to stare out the window while playing those games. If you looked away for even a moment it could turn the tide of the match. With WWE 2k15 just set up a 619 and go make a sandwich. (Results will vary)

To sum up gameplay, even with the problems I pointed out the game is still pretty damn fun to play. You may get annoyed at it from time to time, but you should realize that 2K have built a solid engine here, and it is a great foundation to build the game from. No Mercy came from WCW vs. the World, and Smackdown Here Comes the Pain came from Smackdown 1. So long as 2K continues tweak the game engine with each release we should end up with a great game as soon as 2016.

Creation

Ok Create an everything is gone except for the following.

Wrestlers (male only)

Entrances

movesets

That's it, that's all you've got. How is it you ask?

Create a Wrestler

You have limited morphing of both the body and face. You have far less parts to use compared to previous games. You have less than 20 hair styles. This game is not designed for you to make a perfect clone of AJ Styles or The Great Muta. Nope this game is made for you to make an original wrestler and go through career. Then maybe use the other 24 slots for alt attires to the in game roster. Oh yeah 25 slots is your limit.

Consoles have 500gb hard drives now. PCs can have as much storage as the user is willing to buy, but they could only give us 25 slots for wrestlers because, ~the grapix are so good that the new consoles just can't handle more that 25 of our ultra realistic looking custom wrestlers" (That don't look much better than 2k14 FYI)

Let's get real for a second 2K. The wrestlers are stored as code and tells the game what parts
date: colors and slider settings to use. We are not rendering a full model and saving it to our drives every time we create a wrestler. Your excuse is lazy
recommended:
and it only works on the ill informed. Just like when THQ use to say that they couldn't give us more than 32 CAW slots because they didn't have space on the disc. Ignoring the fact that disc space is a non issue for a line or two of code. WWE games were often shipped out with a GB or two unused.

Entrances

Nope... You will not like it. You can use the entrance parts of SOME of the roster
hoursPlayed: but not all of them. 2K were kind enough to give us mostly entrance moves like Goldust and Fandango
voteText: who really can't be used for other guys. Considering that there is also no custom music (outside of a mod work around) I suggest just skipping entrances. Don't make them
helpfulPercent:
don't watch them. Moving on...

Movesets

Nothing has changed here other than the abilities feature. Basically the abilities work as follows. You want to do top rope moves? Select the ability. You want to do suicide dives? Select the ability. So since he doesn't have the top rope ability the Big Show will go to the second rope for an elbow. Ok got it!

Showcase Mode

This is 30 Years of Wrestlemania mode from 2k14
votesHelpful: just only as a few select feuds. CM Punk vs. John Cena and Shawn Michaels vs. Triple H are the two that come stock with the game. You will wrestle the key matches from these feuds
votesTotal:
while trying to hit the key moves that were hit in the real life matches. You do all of this to take a trip down memory lane and unlock a million alt attires and arenas.

Universe is pretty much what it has always been. Computer selected exhibition matches with a few cut scenes thrown into the mix to give the impression that this is more than random matches.

Career mode is fun until you realize that it's just a grind to (SPOILER ALERT ***** STOP READING) win the WWE Title
votesFunny:
and then the mode fast forward to your retirement match. I hope they continue to work on this mode and get it to the point that it is more like the season modes from Smackdown : Shut Your Mouth and Here Comes the Pain.

Conclusion

I realize that I was short with some of the modes

reviewText:
Pros

Easily moddable, compared to being almost impossible with previous games
Good amount of match modes to play
Official WWE game on the PC with almost every superstar available in the roster and few Hall of Fame extra entries
Random players character invasion (you can get attacked, or helped out)
Others players superstars are downloadable and playable **

Cons

Terribly optimized port for PC and lots of framerate drops, even on match intros...
Repetitive, you grind almost all the time the same enemies all over, until you rank up and get into a better show
Very few backstage scenes, and as far i've see now, all in the same location (no fights as far as i know there)
PC players got the game 6 / 7 months after it has been released for consoles [en.wikipedia.org]
Missing few important superstars male / female rosters.
Lame reversal fight system, it makes you want to quit the game, you're winning, game step up and starts cheating and reversing everything, meanwhile you keep seeing Too early...too late...too early...too late reversal from your side :berserk:
In-fight grapples minigames (Grab an enemy, and start a rock paper scissor game followed by randomly generated controls patterns)
No way to change difficulty for career mode, you're forced to play it with how devs designed it, only avaible in random matches from menu
People creating characters using mods, might ruin your save / lead to permanent game crashes and such once you download them through the game. **
Currently running the game on this setup. [valid.x86.fr]

So far i am currently raging almost all the time, and somewhat enjoying it, if it wasn't for lame cheaty reversal system AI, game would be nice.
Last wrestling game i played, was WWE 2006, which i loved, and yes, thats a long time ago.

But...Never give up.

reviewText:
WWE 2K15 is worth every penny, don't worry about the negative reviews.

This version of the game shouldn't be compared to consoles as the performance varies on different PC systems.

Pros (+):

(+) The graphics of this game is amazing. Compared to WWE 2K14.      [http://i.ytimg.com/vi/OzzQK_1FpKY/maxresdefault.jpg]

(+) The soundtrack is sick (well in my opinion).

(+) Includes all DLCs. :D

(+) The main menu HUD is more organized and gives a modernized look to it.

(+) MyCareer mode is exciting, you get to play as your custom character and upgrade its attributes to become more dominant through the course of the career. You also get to turn face or heel depending on how you fight in game. Another feature I enjoy is that you start off in NXT and work your way up to main eventing PPVs, promoted from NXT, to Superstars, to Main Event, to Smackdown, and then the main show, RAW.

(+) 2K Showcase. Another well done gamemode by 2K. Brings you down memory lane if you have been a long time WWE fan, you get to play through some of the most memorable moments in history. The showcase includes the CM Punk and John Cena feud, the Shawn Michaels and Triple H feud, Mark Henry's Hall of Pain, etc..

(+) WWE Community Creations. In here, you get to download and upload custom superstars, logos, and even move-sets.   The community creations currently are fascinating, since some superstars aren't in the game, you get to download superstars like, Finn Balor, Jeff Hardy, Stardust, Kevin Owens, Razor Ramon, Lana, Mick Foley, and new attires of other superstars.


Cons (-):

(-) No more Create-A-Finisher mode. Ah, the fun days where you could spend hours creating your own ridiculous finisher.

(-) You have a limit of 20 downloads per day for the community creations.

(-) You cannot create your own custom diva. (I wonder how did that guy create Lana..)

(-) When playing online mode, 7 out of 10 games would be against either a guy who has spent hours on end beating people no problem, Main Eventer level, or a troller that doesn't pin you and waits for you to rage quit.

(-) Lots of 1v1 gamemodes gone. NO Inferno match, NO Backstage Brawl, NO 2 out of 3 falls, etc..

(-) 2v2 gamemodes gone too. NO Mixed Tag-Team match, NO Extreme Rules match, NO Ladder match, NO Table match, NO Steel Cage match, NO TLC match, etc..

(-) Finally, there is NO Handicap match whatsoever. :/


Although there are some features missing in the game, the game's still pretty awesome. Hopefully it'll get fixed in 2K16.
WWE 2K15 is worth buying in my opinion, but get it when there's a promotion.
Overall a fun experience and a great game to go to when you have nothing to do. :)
I rate it, 8/10.

reviewText:
Some pretty big bugs right now. How can you not catch such simple issues? Ropes completely disapper, characters stop responding half the time, and if you decline a backgound match the game just goes in a never ending loop of start/stop/start/stop (for lack of a better term to describe it). Also, I attempted to load the game manual from the options menu and there is no PC manual, just for the four consoles. Another simple, but damn useful,  thing to miss.

I'm hoping these bugs will pan out. Aside from bugs, I don't know how I feel about the chain wrestling yet. I like the idea that they're trying to expand the game into a more life-life match, but I don't really care for the randomness that is the circular RS hunting. Makes it more luck than skill if you happen to press the right way (at random) before the other guy. Besides, it's so repetitious in the execution. Not every wrestler performs that way.

I'm going to reserve my right to revisit this after we get some patches and updates. Until then, I'd steer clear from this fiasco.

Update: After playing with the create a wrestler, I am very disappointed. They took out nearly everything that was useful for creation. Every character is going to look the same now because the creation options are woefully stripped down to nothing. This was my absolute favorite part of WWE games and it's a mere shell of what it once was. Unbelievable.

Update 2: So I take the time to attempt creating a wrestler with the extremely limited capabilities this game has, only to find out it's completely pointless for career mode. They wipe out the part of the creation that takes hours to finish (move set). I feel like every time I try something in this game it's just a complete waste of time.

Update 3: This will be my final update. I've tried so hard to make the best of a bad situation. I tried editing my character in career mode and three times I experienced run-time errors that shut down the game and completely lost all my alterations. Around 4 hours in total was lost to crashes. I'm done with WWE 2K15.

reviewText:
Finally, a rasslin' game that gives me the experience I've been looking for!  The pacing of matches mirrors what a real match would be - it's not super fast arcade style fighting, instead taking a more measured approach.  Now, backing off for a minute instead of just attacking constantly isn't just for pretending, it's actually part of the strategy of the match - depending on the type of rasstler you're playing, you might need to control the pace of the match so that you don't over exert yourself.  If you're a more energetic rassler then you'll want to overwhelm your opponent with your superior stamina!

The reversal system feels just right - not too hard, not too easy, and the CPU reverses moves in just the right quantity to make for a good interesting match.  When it comes to submissions it really feels like you're fighting to get your opponent to tap out.

The character creator isn't as robust as it used to be in older WWE games when it comes to molding your character's appearance, but it's still at least average.  There's a good amount of clothing and costume items though.  They My Career mode seems fairly interesting - I like how you get rewarded more for putting on a good match, which means both varying your moves and selling" the match rather than having it be completely one-sided (older games never gave you a reason to do this)."

reviewText:
I recently found myself hit with the nostalgia for the WWE games. I used to play on the ps2 every 2 - 3 years. I would always make 2 clown characters one small one huge. Klown King and Mr. Giggles. I remember one of the releases where I could make the bigger character as tall and fat as possible, but I could launch him across the ring from the top rope landing on an opposing wrestler as I yelled... faaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaat. Aaah memories.

The game can be quite fun to play, but only once you start to get the hang of it. At first the game is a counter game. There is a weird, lag or sluggish feeling that the characters have off and on. Even when they have full stamina. This causes the player to leave himself open while attempting to make a grapple but the game does not respond. But once the player adapts to this, the AI is easily countered. Eventually allowing for more strikes (punches/kicks) to come out.

I was playing this game and had logged in a whole lot of time on it when I hit a bug. It literally broke the game to the point to where I was unable to save characters. My first career character was fine but the second character did not save properly and was just bugged. Here is what happened. The first character I made was made in My Creation and then imported into my career. The second character was created in my career and eventually exported to the rest of the game. I believe that the second character somehow broke the game. The break doesn't become apparent until you attempt to use the second character in other parts of the game and you cannot export that character until completing my career. If you want to learn how to fix this bug check out the fix in my review video!

If you are looking for a really great wrestling game this isn't it. But if you are looking for a wrestling game tide you over, this could be it.  In a few months from now there may be mods that fix a lot of the issues with this game if 2K doesn't step up to the plate by then.

For more details, click below.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ug7hgftM2DA

reviewText:
Game works great, pretty much 60fps constant at 1080p with MSAA 8x and everything maxed out. Graphics is absolutely remarkable with sharp textures, realistic animations and large no. of audiences in the arena etc.

Gameplay is a bit slow and needs getting used to but the main issue is the steep learning curve and difficulty of the counter system (RT). The game needs a tutorial mode.

Replays and highlights are bugged currently, no animations happening.

The presentation and commentary are good, compared to previous WWE games, and the character roster is huge (apart from unlockables and DLC)

Free DLC gets a lot of points here since there are more to come.

Well done overall. We hope to see the missing features/match types implemented in future installments

reviewText:
I was on the fence for quite a while about this game because of a lot of the negative reviews.  I played 2k14 on a cousin's PS3 and had a great time, so I thought I would give this a try once it came on sale. I'm glad I did. I generally suck at these type of games because I can never get myself out of the button mashing mindset. This has changed all that. I lost a bit at first, but once I got into the MyCareer mode and started off with the tutorial, I began to really appreciate the timing aspects of everything. To me, it actually feels like the old N64 wrestling games, and that's a good thing.  The graphics are incredible on my 970 and i have barely noticed any stuttering.  If you're on the fence, give it a try. Worst case, you can get a refund. Best case, like me, you might actually enjoy it.

Pros:
Difficulty is just right, at least for this reviewer
Graphics
A lot of modes
50 save spaces and downloading of additional creations is a breeze

Cons:
Infrequent stuttering or failure to start game
At first, the rock, paper, scissors minigame for tieups is a bit confusing
Would be nice to have a training mode for practicing stuff

reviewText:
(( IGNORE MY HOURS LOGGED ON STEAM, I HAVE PUT THOUSANDS INTO THE CONSOLE VERSION ))

Instead of whining about missing features until the cows come home, i'm going to actually be diplomatic and truthful.

GRAPHICS: 10
GAMEPLAY: 9
REALISM: 10
SOUND: 8

This review is without bias, be aware that i've played Wrestling games as a whole (not just WWE/F games) since the early 90s, as long as playing other annual sports titles such as this title. Being a wrestler myself i can tell you that besides the blurred lines of what is shoot and not shoot in MyCareer, this game helps you get as close to the real experience of wrestling as possible with a video game.

This is the same WWE 2k15 that was realeased in NOV/OCT 2014, DO NOT i repeat DO NOT expect a 2K16 roster with theme songs, attires, videos etc.. for example dont expect:

Seth Rollins New Attire and Theme Song

Catch my drift? However the modding scene for this game is growing at an increiblt rapid speed on both the 2K forums and Smacktalks, so if your willing to mod some things for yourself, as it stands Titantrons, Music, Minitrons and Textures are all being worked on and some of those are already possible.

Be warned that if you are looking for an Arcade experience this game is really really not for you, this is very much a simulation title.

OVERALL : 9/10

reviewText:
Not even sure why there is so much hate on this game. This game is amazing and they stepped it up lots from the past 3-4 years of the other games. I always thought this game would just be the same as WWE 2k12-2k14. In my mind those games were simply the same. In WWE 2K15 they stepped it up lots making it more fun and having many more things 2 do. I know people might not like this PC port for this game but that's no reason to hate on the game.

People are just mad because they don't have the right PC to play this game. Warning: You do need a decent computer to run this game. Anyways, this game is simply amazing. It's action packed with realistic and fun game modes. The graphics this year has improved by lots from the other games and they really picked it up.

Alright, let's start with the game modes. First we have the My Career gamemode. This is a little action packed and fun. First you start off making your own WWE superstar. After you make ya superstar you get to go and have one match showing that you earned the contract to be a WWE Superstar. You do 2-3 matches testing how well you do etc. You move onto the NXT show and start doing tuns of matches. In this mode your superstar is really weak and has very little skill as you go on in everymatch you get points and with these points you can make your WWE superstar better. Such as making them run faster, OMG momments, grapple skills etc. You fight with NXT for a while then you move on and win the NXT championship. Then you move onto Main Event, then superstarts than Smackdown and last Raw. You come across a few titles during that time and have issues and fight with others in the locker room and such through soical media. Sometimes, you are put to a task such as Get a 5 star match in atleast 2-4 of the matches you are playing. Hours and hours go by fighting and building up your superstar then you get a shot at the WWE championship then you retire.

WWE 2K SHOWCASE is really fun. It's bringing real life events to the video game such as "Path Of the Warrior" and so on. This gamemode is taking real life WWE moments and putting it into the game so you can relive those moments in a video game. It's very fun and you get tasks that you must do.

WWE Universe mode is a fun gamemode to play that you can spend over 1
recommended: 000 hours on and still have a fun time. You do matches and paper views like you would do in real life. It's your own world and you can do whatever you like with the matches. Universe mode takes you into a GM type section where you can do what you want and like such as Making John Cena face Seth Rollins for the WWE championship at WrestleMania.\n\nThese are the three main points on why I think WWE 2k15 is an amazing game and filled with action packed

reviewText:
Well I've been a fan of the series since the very early days back in the 1980's, and after waiting for a decent PC version for a good 12 years, I'm finally pleased to say this is a pretty decent port, my only real issue is in the mapping of the trigger for the dodge attacks, might be remappable but otherwise find it annoying positioning due to not being gamepad user of regular basis.

That aside, this looks the business, and plays pretty well (having played it on the x360 and PS2 is years past) and seems to dropped most of the button mashing for more tactical timing methods. The game itself seems to be frame capped to 60fps (30fps on cutscenes / enterances) regardless whether playing in 1080p or 4k resolution... not that it really need over 60fps.

Given there really is not other choice of wrestling games on PC worth a damn, this is instantly the best game of it's type on our beloved platform, can't wait to see all the mods down the line.

reviewText:
If you're looking for an exciting WWE xperience, his could be it.

Pros:

Cons:
- CAW system is limited(My own dsign requires something more elaborate than the basic stuff!)
- Sloppy control system(Day of Reckoning 2 on Gamecube did it right, WWE'12/'13 on Wii were better)
- Counter system and grapple system rely too much on reflex minigames!(AI/CPU ALWAYS counter when your countring is either too fast or too slow, never on the mark!)
- Momentum system too much like WWF Warzone where you can lose th crowd's interest too quickly!

Suggstions: 2K, look at THQ's old data files from oldr WWE/WWF games! Notice how in Day of Reckoning 2 and even WWE'12/'13 the grapple system was less about minigames and more about getting it done! Do like they did and simplify the controls again! And WTF is with the 3D bing so difficult to perform?! Even in WWF No Mrcy it was way easier! And the tag tam match deal, you could get disqualified for staying in he ring too long?! ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T! This game needs a lot of repair work! Let's hope WWE 2K16 has thse issues fixed up!

I'd recommend it if you're a WWE fan who has been aching for a nw game on the PC. Otherwise... Keep waiting, this one is quite a mess.

reviewText:
I had been hoping to see a PC version of WWE. Been playing quite a few on Xbox 360. Just teh past 2 years I haven't bought a game. So eagerly I waited for it to arrive. Pre-Bought, and played the game. Excitement was beheld, as the load screen came up.  Overjoyed as I was able to browse the menus. Quickly I picked the first option to Play a Single match. Selected my guy Bray Wyatt... Randomly let the computer pick its wrestler, it picked Cesaro.
Nice entrances and such, then the bell rang.  Using my 360 controller, I moved in for the attack, did my first move. No problem. Then it came to defending, WHAT THE HECK, press RT to defend (ok ok, I can kinda live with that. Just need to learn timing). But worst is the Right Stick when it come to jocking for a postion. What the heck are they thinking? This is suppuse to be fast paced. Quick in an outs, Not some namby-pamby rotate your stick.
I liked the old school style a lot better. Bring back the old format that was on Xbox and I am sure Playstation...
Now that that was said, I would recommend if you can come to grips with the controller setting. the game looks so nice and such. Graphics are up there. Animation is great. (Replays look a little weird at times)
Learning curve is a bit steep at first if you have not ventured into this type of game before. But if you are patient I am sure that the WRESTLING PLEASURE is there for you to enjoy.
I will keep trying to plug a way at this a bit more. And hope I can update this to give a more informed opinion. This is only after playing the game for not even a hour. (Only did 3 matches as of this writing)

reviewText:
My review:

I've played WWE 2K15 first on the Playstation 4. The reason I bought this for the PC is because I'm looking forward to mods.

Graphics: 10/10
Honestly, the graphics on next gen consoles were a huge improvement over WWE 2K14 and the PC just gives us that full HD movement.

Gameplay: 10/10
Can't say anything negative about the gameplay. I use the xbox 360 remote.

Loading times: 10/10
The loading times are very fast for me.

Music: 10/10
I've heard these songs hundreds of times and probably memorised them by now. It's a good soundtrack but there's not a lot of songs and they will tire eventually. You obviously have the option to turn the music off.

- Not as much customization as previous WWE games
Basically you can't create diva's, which sucks as there aren't many in the game inititally. You also can't create arena's, titles or finishers like previous games. The entrance creation is limited with existing superstars entrances and only a few custom options.

- Not all the DLC is available yet.

If you enjoy WWE and like the look of the gameplay on YouTube etc I recommend you get this. If you only want this for mods then you should probably wait untill people have figured out how to mod the game and there actually are mods out.

reviewText:
While I'm aware that WWE 2K15 uses new engine. thus some things have to be remade, there are no excuses for some of the major flaws that exist. The WWE SvR and WWE12-14 had some of the most complex and indepth character customizations that have ever existed in Videogames. This is the main reason why many people adore these games and why many choose to buy them.

That said, WWE 2k15's Create-A-Wrestler features are so painfuly neutered that it's the one of the most limited to have ever exist in a WWE game. It's downright offensive. To give you an example, WWE13 had a total of 86 hairstyles available....WWE 2k15 has a total of 18. Yeah no ♥♥♥♥, it's that bad. I'm not entirely sure who to point the finger on this one. I have a feeling that 2K games had a role in influencing Yuke Games. That or Yuke Games didn't have enough time. What I do know however is that there are no new game modes and some were taken out.

So if you're looking to make a wild selection of characters like Duke Nukem Vs Star Fox then you're out of luck.

Only reason I would recommend buying this game is to prove to 2K that porting to the PC is well worth it. It is true that this is the first WWE game to have ever come to the PC, so lets hope for future installments that they keep that going.

Also the game is slow as ♥♥♥♥ and apparently doesn't use the mouse whatsoever. Holy ♥♥♥♥ why.

reviewText: In sort, don't buy unless it's on offer, in it's current state DO NOT buy at full price. Aside from common graphical issues that should have been caught during testing like dissapearing ropes, failure to initialize ragdolls during replays and cutscenes (models just lay crumpled on the floor), the counter attack system is a joke, 50% of the time the counter icon is out of sync with the attack, resulting in a ''too fast'' or ''too slow'' message despite the counter icon being visible, as well as the A.I occassionaly ignoring your counter attacks completely anyway even if you do get lucky. for the customization seems thin attire wise, visualy theres nothing impressive either, I'm really wondering how this game takes up 30GB. The career mode is locked to normal so if you're getting annoyed at the cheating A.I you can't adjust the difficulty or modify the A.I's abilities (frequency they can counter ect). I bought this game out of nostalgia and recieved a brutal reminder to how much some developers are happy with bare minimum effort, I'm pretty dissapointed. Side note, not that it's overly important but the music list in this game is not only shockingly small and (down to personal tase granted) rubbish.

reviewText:
~This is a port report, not a full review of the game~

*Playing with a i7 4790k/GTX970/16GB Ram/Win8.1*

So far the game runs at a rock solid 60FPS. There is no 120/144hz support from the looks of it (it recognizes the refresh rate but it doesn't matter due to the locked 60 in game). Entrances are a locked 30. There is no controller rebinding but there is full Keyboard rebinding. This game seems to have zero mouse support as of right now. There is a major bug with the Red Box Moment" that can happen in the middle of a match. Random fire will shoot out of the ring and the ropes/announce tables will disappear and everyone in the crowd does a T Pose (see my screenshots for an example).

Online play is inexcusably laggy to the point where the pin meters don't work and matches will move in slow motion. It's unplayable. Trying to view leaderboards cause an instant crash of the game. The voice chat seems to be always on as well. Make sure to mute your mic if you decide to play online.


Graphic Options wise you are very limited. You have Anti-Aliasing (up to 8x MSAA & FXAA)
voteText: VSync and a tessellation setting. That about covers it. No texture resolution or anything to choose shockingly. Audio Options have plenty of sliders to get just the perfect sound levels.\n\nOverall it's a middle of the road port. If you plan on doing single player or local MP then the game will be just fine. Online as of now is in a pitiful state and the game should NOT be purchased for that feature alone. The game doesn't come with Paige either which is just heartbreaking. Still
helpfulPercent: it's the first WWE game on PC since 2002 and it's not a total disaster!\n\nEDIT: One more MAJOR thing to note. Pretty much none of the DLC is in the game now. If you bought this expecting to play some of it
votesHelpful: you're out of luck. It'll apparently be available for download soon. Also
votesTotal: for the second time...no Paige. 2K please :(."

reviewText:
This review is based on my first impressions of the game, coming from last playing a WWE game on the 360 a few years ago and on the PS2 before that. My opinion may change in the future when the games patched as will this review.

The Game Itself:

The games current state in my opinion (from what I've seen) is fine, people are having issues at the moment of various things such as invisible robes, low fps, crashing, won't launch, laptop problems. I haven't had these issues, unfortunately for them so I can't relate however. My ONLY issue currently with this game is My Career mode and Create a Superstar which I will mention later in the review.

Another thing to mention is, people seem to be confused about the DLC. Yes, it is ALL free, but its not all here on day one release it will released eventually as a free update. For now we have the Hogan and Sting character packs.

The game looks stunningly good compared to the past WWE games I'm used to, of course the audience still look a slight bit odd but its fine. Animations look really well done and smooth although movement when walking and running can feel a bit janky but I got used to it. You can use Keyboard and Mouse or Gamepad, I haven't tried K/M at all but the Gamepad works just fine. One thing I dislike about the game/controls is 'chain wrestling' where you grapple your opponent and choose 3 options, if yours is the same as the opponents then you try again until someone wins, once that's over you move the right stick around an axis to find a sweet spot then hold it there to do a grapple to your opponent, then you do it again and if they win they do something to you and it goes on, I could go on forever. This mechanic just feels so weird to me and basically luck based, its so out of place from what I'm used to before, luckly tho! I found in the 'gameplay balancing' options you could somewhat disable it which is quite handy.

The game also has this, replay mechanic where you watch your character do there finisher again? to me, why would I need to see it again. To me its not needed so I turned it off, there's also highlights at the end of a match where it shows the 'best' bits of the match between the two fighters. Now my issue with this is, it starts and the commentator says Lets watch some highlights of the match" then when the next one starts
recommended:
and again.. so I turned it off as it was annoying.

Game Modes:

The game features a ton! of content

reviewText:
A solid return to the PC platform, thanks in part to 2K's familiarity with the system. Some visual jankiness from the consoles is still present (and can be fixed by removing camera cuts), but all in all a decent PC port with hours worth of gameplay in both MyCareer and WWE Universe mode.

Another neat little addition is the 2K Showcase, where the meat of the game (characters, arenas, clothes) is unlocked. The base game itself contains the 2011 feud between the now departed CM Punk and John Cena and the 2002-3 feud between lifelong friends Triple H and Shawn Michaels. Additional Showcase feuds will be added through the already included DLC, but the release date on those is TBA.

Graphically, the game looks a LOT better than previous iterations. Unlike '13 and 2K14, where every main roster wrestler looked like CAWs with custom textures, the character models here are top notch. Even minor things like the referee, the audience, and background filler have been upgraded to better fit the next-gen experience.

reviewText: WWE 2K15 on PC will be the optimal version of this game and is the best choice for buyers, the reason i say will be is because I have only one complaint and it's that there are a few bugs and a couple glitches but at the time of this review it's only been out for a day and will be obviously patched soon. I'm comparing this to the PS4/XBOXONE version's of this game, i thought on a technical standpoint it would be hard to beat because for the first time on a console, a WWE game is at 60 frames locked with no drops and the highest graphic setting which looks great. But the PC version is equal to that if not better because of PC's graphic choices.  The game is an exact port of the PS4/XBOXONE version, and the big complaint with 2K15 and why i say this is the best choice is that the original game is lacking in the depth in characters, modes, and more things to do unless you shell out 30 dollars for a season pass to get 3 more showcase stories instead of the regular 2. The season pass adds lot's of new characters and additions which fills the empty spots int he original game. Except on PC it's all included with the game without paying for any of the DLC. So on a financial point getting it for 54.99 or 49.99 when i got it on sale pre-ordered. Is a much better deal than getting it on console for 69.99 and paying an additional 30 dollars for a season pass. So PC is definitely the best option for WWE 2K15 and takes everything good with the next gen console versions and improves it, only con was the few bugs that will be fixed. PC MASTER RACE OuO

reviewText:
As a pretty significantly huge fan of pro wrestling (I've essentially been watching it since I was two years old, when my grandfather would watch it while I was little), I've been waiting quite a long while for a moddable PC version of a wrestling game. So, you can imagine my delight when it was suddenly announced out of nowhere that WWE 2K15 was getting a release in all of half a week. Unfortunately, what I ended up getting was so terrible that even my fandom was not enough to blind me to it.

Firstly, the game is unoptimized as hell. I've got what I'd consider a pretty decent gaming computer. Everything EXCEPT this game I've been able to run on high, if not ultra high settings. Yet, with this game the only way I've even remotely been able to make the game playable is to turn all of the rather meager settings to the lowest available option, as well as turning the crowd completely off so right off the bat the immersion they're going for is destroyed. You will NOT find options such as being able to toggle texture quality and whatnot to help you run the game better.

Secondly, I ran into a very massive game breaking issue. After plugging away 30 hours or so into the game and basically unlocking 98% of the unlockables, I thought I'd start messing around with WWE Universe mode. I had completely 100% completed 2K Showcase Mode. I had completely finished MyCareer mode. It was basically all I had left to do. So, in order to make Universe more interesting I downloaded some community created Create-A-Wrestlers. ...and after a few of them suddenly they were all giving me save corruption messages. A message that would pop up any time I went into any menu. I attempted to fix the issue, using a guide that some fan made. Unfortunately this guide had zero effect on my copy and the only way I had to fix the problem was to basically reset the game - losing EVERYTHING I had unlocked, and finished to this point. 30 hours down the drain. As you might imagine, I'm not exactly too enthusiastic to do it all over again in the hopes that it won't just mess up again later when I get to the point where I'm ready to mess with Universe mode again.

While I won't complain about the fact that not all of the DLC is available as the store page did mention some being released later - I admit I don't really understand why. This game is basically a direct port of the PS4/Xbox One editions. I'm not even convinced they didn't merely just download the disc data over and call it a day without tweaking it. On those consoles all of the DLC is already released. So why the delay? At the very least why delay the accelerator DLC which would allow me to simply toggle everything as unlocked when the entire game went to hell and I needed to start over? I also don't truly understand why Paige isn't available at all. I get that she was season pass exclusive. But the data is clearly there somewhere and you chose to not do the season pass on PC. Why not simply throw her in later along with the rest? It just screams lack of effort on their part.

As for the game itself? The game is greatly hollow compared to previous years on consoles. A good chunk of match types are flat out missing. You cannot create a female wrestler in the CAW even though there is actually an unlockable that requires you to win a match WITH a created female. Another sign they just simply didn't care to edit the game to remove something leftover from a previous incarnation. MyCareer was interesting, but was somewhat poorly implimented and often came off as more tedious than interesting. Storylines were simply too spaced out and most of your career consisted of doing tune-up matches for the sake of having a match. Often I'd get a storyline that would tell me that if I beat X amount of matches I'd get a title shot - and then when I beat all the matches Triple H would tell me that he can't give me the title shot now, but someday he would promise to give me one for realsies. It just made the majority of the career feel pointless. In addition when you win the world title, the entire career mode ends which is a shame as your feuds as world champion would have likely been the most interesting part.

2K Showcase mode was interesting enough, as it allows you to relive two famous rivalries and the key matches that went along with them - but it wasn't anything we hadn't seen before already with the 30 years of WrestleMania gimmick in a previous title. Also, unlocking old versions of current roster members who have little to no difference in their moves and mannerisms rather than simply making it an alternate attire just seems silly. Also silly: Unlocking no less than three HBK ring attires that are the same ring attire with a slightly different vest during his entrance while actively showing you photos and video footage of the clearly different ring attire it's supposed to be. Decent, but not game-saving.

Create-A-Story, and Create-A-Arena are gone. Additionally, you are limited to a set amount of downloads a day (when they're not simply corrupting your entire save halfway through them). You're limited to 25 CAWs, even though logically a computer would have infinite space to allow you as many as you'd like.

I want to give this game nothing but rousing praise in the hopes more games get released in the future. I simply can't. If I was giving this a score rating out of 10 it would be a 5 if I was being generous. I can't recommend it. I got it as a gift, and I feel kind of bad my friend paid 50 bucks for it. This game is worth 20 tops.

reviewText:
Has very limited creation. It has taken many steps backwards in types of matches and character creation. However the MyCareer mode is fantastic, the graphics are amazing, it takes a more realistic approach, rather than the fast pace you have in the WWE/SvR games, and it still manages to be really fun to play.

The character creation, being so limited, makes it a huge disappointment, and as you can guess, takes out a lot of the fun. But the approach it takes on gameplay and the graphics it has, is amazing. It isn't worth $50 in my opinion. So I recommend waiting for it to go on sale. It is still a great game. The only con to gameplay in my opinion, is the grappling, rather than press A faster than your opponent to win a grapple chain, you instead have a rock, paper, scissors-like system which makes it feel more like chance to win, rather than determination and actually feeling apart of the match.

Other than that. Still a good game. Get it when it goes on sale. Do NOT get it at full price.

Final Score: I give this game a 7/10 only because It's the first PC port and because of my

Most critics would give it a 6-6.5/10 at most.

reviewText:
Good game but feels like its extremely Early Access.

Full of stupid asthetic bugs eg. ropes disappearing then reappearing in the centre of the ring! Replays are non-existant and are instead a picture of your wrestler in the ring with no ropes (again).

Was thrilled when i saw this coming out on PC but sadly 2k have yet again proven that they cant be bothered testing the game. The bugs are so obvious, all you have to do is play 1 wrestling match and their there, right in front of your very own eyes!!! Seeing as this is supposed to be a wrestling game i would have thought they would test at least one wrestling match before releasing the game!!! Also 2k are yet to fix the issue of not being able to create divas, an issue thats existed since the release of the console versions (over 6 months ago).

Other than the bugs the game seems to run smoothly. I havent hit any bugs affecting performance so if you dont mind the game looking a bit wrong i would recommend it. Sadly after 7 hours the visual bugs are starting to annoy me. Would also like an option to import sound tracks, this wasnt done on the console versions but it makes no sense to not include the feature on the PC version seeing as computers tend to have music stored on them.

Overall I would just about recommend WWE 2K15. The bugs are annoying but should be fixed if 2k can be bothered. Regardless of the bugs the actual game is great and runs smoother than the console versions that ive played on (PS4 and Xbox One) which, in my opinion, outweighs the asthetic issues.

reviewText:
For the first time in a loooong time we finally have a WWE game on PC. Its a next gen game so it looks amazing and surprisingly very stable as well on a half decent gaming rig.

A few points:

Career Mode is very bare bones was really a struggle to keep playing at times. The ground work is there though so im hoping 2K16 will improve on this. There were a few rivalries and storylines but they were few and far between, it seemed at times to be just one match after another with very little build up for the big matches.

The actual gameplay is IMO very good. It took me a while to get used to the chain wrestling and quick reversal controls but when i did my matches were very fluid and satisfying. Be prepared for frustration though early on as it is radically different.

The Create a Superstar feature wasnt too shabby but again seemed to have less features than previous titles. Create a Diva is foremost amongst these. Maybe work in progress for 2k16.

Would have also liked to have seen a bigger roster of past and present superstars so again..il hoping next title they will build on this and give us that bit more than this time around.

All in all its a pretty good game that gave me over 40 hours of playtime, just a few features that need extra attention in the next title.

I forgive them though since its the first game for next gen and im hoping most PC gamers will support this so we continue to get wrestling games now and in the future.

reviewText:
Pro-wrestling games have been few and far between on the PC, primarily being the domain of consoles only. When it was recently announced on WWE.COM that last year’s WWE 2K15 was going to be ported to PC, I was ecstatic. There hadn’t been a PC wrestling game since WWF In Your House back in 1996, and it was long overdue. WWE 2K15 from developers Visual Concepts/Yukes and publisher 2K Sports has some fairly small boots to fill, and anything was better than nothing. Gone is the arcade-style control schemes, power-ups or special Mortal Kombat attacks. Sadly, no, you cannot summon a tombstone from The Undertaker, but you can GIVE a Tombstone Piledriver as the Undertaker, so there’s that.

Sad to say, though, once you leave the Gorilla Position and go through the curtain, the presentation – much like the current WWE product – is lacking in substance and style.

Let’s get the elephant out of the room; this is a straight port of the XBOX One/PS4 version that was released in 2014. Since this is a direct port, I could easily cop out and just say “find a console review.” However, because I love you all so very much, I’m going to pretend for the moment that there was no such thing as a console release and thoroughly run this game through the ringer, so if you want to skip to the end and rage at the numbers, I understand. However, the biggest issue with a console-to-PC port is that all the issues (and I do mean “all”) will be copied over en masse. Shoddy hit-detection, graphical/audio glitches, muddy textures, and otherwise lackluster presentation detract from the overall package. Fear not, though, as there’s a legitimate reason to pick up this game if you’re a solid PC gamer, which I’ll discuss below.

From the get-go, you’re given a paltry twenty or so Superstars to choose from (and what little remains of the women’s “Diva” division) with the majority of them are locked away from use until you play either the “The Streak” featuring The Undertaker, 2K Showcase mode, or the much-touted MyCareer mode. Both have their pros and cons, but you’ll need to play through both of the latter if you ever want to unlock your personal favorite Superstar or if you simply grow tired of beating down Kofi Kingston or Heath Slater for the hundredth time. (Seriously, why does Heath Slater still have employment?)

This game CAN be played with a keyboard, but, trust, me, you’re not going to want that. The controls are, in a word, clunky. At first, anyway. No matter your skill-level or experiences, you’re going to have a bit of learning curve when starting your first matches. Control schemes are simplified to a strike/grapple system, with moves being context-sensitive to what direction you push on the movement stick as well as what condition your opponent is in. For example, the same button-presses that allow you to suplex someone from a standing position will also allow you to stomp someone’s face in if they’re lying down on the mat. While this is inherently simplistic, you’ll find yourself accidentally pulling off moves you didn’t intend, which can lead to lost matches on a frustratingly-high basis.

Also, if you’re ever feeling down, turn on Anti-Aliasing in the options and watch a replay; it’s a guaranteed (currently) glitch that results in the ring-posts and ropes vanishing, defaults the crowd to arms-outstretched models, and all player/NPC characters face-down on the mat. It’s a thing of beauty. That said, the glitches are near-constant, but never to the point where the game is unplayable. You’re still going to scream on occasion when your grapple turns into your Superstar climbing the turnbuckle… From the ladder you were on just moments before. Teleportation seems to be everyone’s domain in WWE 2K15, not just The Undertaker and Bray Waytt.

Overall, for an initial offering, WWE 2K15 shows plenty of promise as a rookie. Sure, it’s easy to write the game off as a sub-par experience, but regardless of all the issues, the game is still a blast for any wrestling fan and worth a purchase. In my opinion, modding is going to be the thing that keeps this game out of the unemployment line or late-night infomercials, fixing the various glitches and using “unofficial patches,” wherever possible to breathe new life into this soon-to-be-stagnant game. As it stands currently, the game is a B+ player at best, maybe even dipping into the “backyard wrestling” variety. Still, WWE 2K16 is going to have to up their efforts, but for now, the game is begging for more content, which the PC community looks primed and ready to deliver.

reviewText:
Listen, I need to state one thing right here.
If WWE 2K16 comes out to PC then there is absolutely no reason to purchase this game. None. From what I can tell its everything 2K15 was and MUCH more.
However, if it doesnt come out for PC and you dont have a current gen console, then I'm sure you can make do with this.
I dont know how to feel about this game, because what it does well it does very well, its gameplay isnt too bad and the graphics were the best for WWE games when it came out.
But the game lacks so many features that practically became standard with previous games and I find myself prefering my PS3 copy of  WWE 2K14 over this much more.
Dont get me wrong, I dont hate this game. But I cant help but feel dissapointed in it. And if 2K16 makes it grand debut on PC then this game becomes obsolete. It wont have the charm for me many old WWE games have sadly.
So yeah, only buy this game if theres no other options. Its fine and all, but severely lacking in many areas.

reviewText:
Pro-wrestling games have been few and far between on the PC, primarily being the domain of consoles only. When it was recently announced on WWE.COM that last year’s WWE 2K15 was going to be ported to PC, I was ecstatic. There hadn’t been a PC wrestling game since WWF In Your House back in 1996, and it was long overdue. WWE 2K15 from developers Visual Concepts/Yukes and publisher 2K Sports has some fairly small boots to fill, and anything was better than nothing. Gone is the arcade-style control schemes, power-ups or special Mortal Kombat attacks. Sadly, no, you cannot summon a tombstone from The Undertaker, but you can GIVE a Tombstone Piledriver as the Undertaker, so there’s that.

Sad to say, though, once you leave the Gorilla Position and go through the curtain, the presentation – much like the current WWE product – is lacking in substance and style.

Let’s get the elephant out of the room; this is a straight port of the XBOX One/PS4 version that was released in 2014. Since this is a direct port, I could easily cop out and just say “find a console review.” However, because I love you all so very much, I’m going to pretend for the moment that there was no such thing as a console release and thoroughly run this game through the ringer, so if you want to skip to the end and rage at the numbers, I understand. However, the biggest issue with a console-to-PC port is that all the issues (and I do mean “all”) will be copied over en masse. Shoddy hit-detection, graphical/audio glitches, muddy textures, and otherwise lackluster presentation detract from the overall package. Fear not, though, as there’s a legitimate reason to pick up this game if you’re a solid PC gamer, which I’ll discuss below.

From the get-go, you’re given a paltry twenty or so Superstars to choose from (and what little remains of the women’s “Diva” division) with the majority of them are locked away from use until you play either the “The Streak” featuring The Undertaker, 2K Showcase mode, or the much-touted MyCareer mode. Both have their pros and cons, but you’ll need to play through both of the latter if you ever want to unlock your personal favorite Superstar or if you simply grow tired of beating down Kofi Kingston or Heath Slater for the hundredth time. (Seriously, why does Heath Slater still have employment?)

This game CAN be played with a keyboard, but, trust, me, you’re not going to want that. The controls are, in a word, clunky. At first, anyway. No matter your skill-level or experiences, you’re going to have a bit of learning curve when starting your first matches. Control schemes are simplified to a strike/grapple system, with moves being context-sensitive to what direction you push on the movement stick as well as what condition your opponent is in. For example, the same button-presses that allow you to suplex someone from a standing position will also allow you to stomp someone’s face in if they’re lying down on the mat. While this is inherently simplistic, you’ll find yourself accidentally pulling off moves you didn’t intend, which can lead to lost matches on a frustratingly-high basis.

Also, if you’re ever feeling down, turn on Anti-Aliasing in the options and watch a replay; it’s a guaranteed (currently) glitch that results in the ring-posts and ropes vanishing, defaults the crowd to arms-outstretched models, and all player/NPC characters face-down on the mat. It’s a thing of beauty. That said, the glitches are near-constant, but never to the point where the game is unplayable. You’re still going to scream on occasion when your grapple turns into your Superstar climbing the turnbuckle… From the ladder you were on just moments before. Teleportation seems to be everyone’s domain in WWE 2K15, not just The Undertaker and Bray Waytt.

Overall, for an initial offering, WWE 2K15 shows plenty of promise as a rookie. Sure, it’s easy to write the game off as a sub-par experience, but regardless of all the issues, the game is still a blast for any wrestling fan and worth a purchase. In my opinion, modding is going to be the thing that keeps this game out of the unemployment line or late-night infomercials, fixing the various glitches and using “unofficial patches,” wherever possible to breathe new life into this soon-to-be-stagnant game. As it stands currently, the game is a B+ player at best, maybe even dipping into the “backyard wrestling” variety. Still, WWE 2K16 is going to have to up their efforts, but for now, the game is begging for more content, which the PC community looks primed and ready to deliver.
